div.p:
Some interesting correspondence has passed between Baron
Humboldt and the Mexican Government. In a letter from
Lucas Alaman, Secretary of State for the Mexican Republic,
his Excellency states that the Baron’s luminous writings rela-
tive to America had been received with general satisfaction,
and that the rending of the work had not a little contributed to
vivify the spirit of independence, the germs of which existed
amongst many of the inhabitants, and to arouse others from
the lethargy in which they were held by foreign domination.
The Government heartily concurring in the general sentiment,
had directed his Excellency to express their lively hope that he
would carry his intention into effect, of once more returning
to Mexico, so that they might congratulate themselves on
counting amongst the number of the inhabitants of the Re-
public, a man so illustious and justly esteemed throughout
the civilized world. The Baron, in reply, says, “Engaged
in a career dedicated entirely to the cultivation of the sciences,
and to the support of the eternal principles on which the pro-
gress of reason, and the amelioration of public institutions de-
pend, nothing could flatter myself-love more than this solemn
testimony, expressed in so noble and in teresting a manner. I
therefore beg your Excellency to present to your Government
this homage of my profound respect, and of my eternal grati-
tude. If the works which I have published have produced any
good, it should be attributed only to my love for the truth and
the purity of my sentiments, and to the admiration with which
I have been inspired by a country whom nature has destined
to so exalted a fate. I am not without hope of beholding once
again (my Sovereign permitting) the majestic Corderillas of
Anahauc; and of studying once more their natural produc-
tions; and of enjoying the pleasure of witnessing happi-
ness which must necessarily be produced in the bosom of the
Republic, by free institutions and the arts of peace.”
